concepts.unlisted_label: Unexplained Delay in Disposal of Detenu's Representation

issues.text: whether the matters mentioned in the grounds furnished to the petitioners are absolutely false

anchor.surface_text: The counsel very strenuously urged that the matters mentioned in the grounds furnished to the petitioners are absolutely false. According to him the petitioners are all educated persons and that they have been only writing articles pleading for improving the lot of the people of Manipur and for giving due recognition to the hopes and aspirations of the people of Manipur. The counsel has also urged that the grounds of detention are all vague and it was not possible for the detenus to make any effective representation against such vague allegations.

issues.text: whether the grounds of detention are all vague and it was not possible for the detenus to make any effective representation against such vague allegations

anchor.surface_text: The counsel has also urged that the grounds of detention are all vague and it was not possible for the detenus to make any effective representation against such vague allegations. The counsel further urged that in any event, there has been an inordinate delay, of 17 days in the Administrator disposing of the representation made by the petitioners and as such there has been a violation of Art. 22  5   of the Constitution.

issues.text: whether there has been an inordinate delay of 17 days in disposing of the representation and violation of Art. 22(5) of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: The counsel further urged that in any event, there has been an inordinate delay, of 17 days in the Administrator disposing of the representation made by the petitioners and as such there has been a violation of Art. 22  5   of the Constitution. Therefore, the detention orders will have to be struck down even on this short ground., On the other hand, according to the affidavit filed on behalf of the State, all the petitioners are active members of the Pan Manipuri Youth League which is an Over-ground Organisation of the Under-ground insurgents in Manipur.

issues.text: whether there has been any delay in disposing of the representation made by the petitioners, and if so, whether that delay has been properly explained by the State

anchor.surface_text: In dealing with the. question whether there has been any delay in disposing of the representation made by the petitioners, and if so, whether that delay has been properly explained by the State, it may be relevant to mention only one of the ground,, for detention. In ground No. 4, it has been alleged that the petitioners and other leaders of the Pan Manpuri Youth League held a secret meeting on December 13, 1970 between 7 P.M. and 9 P.M. wherein it was decided to boycott the Republic Day functions to be held on January 26 1971 at Manipur and to disrupt the celebrations by violent means.

issues.text: whether there were materials on the basis of which the detaining authority could have passed the orders of detention under s. 3(2) read with s. 3(1) of the Act

anchor.surface_text: However, we should say that prima facie we are satisfied that the grounds are neither vague nor devoid of particulars, nor can it be said that in this case there were no materials on the basis of which the detaining authority could have passed the orders of detention under s. 3 2  read with s. 3 1  of the Act for the purpose mentioned therein on the basis of the grounds furnished to the petitioners.

anchor.surface_text: From what is stated above, it is clear that the State was fully aware... it must be held that there has been an unexplained delay of 17 days in this case in the Government disposing of the representation of the detenus.

arguments.claim: precedent: unexplained delay (e.g. 16 days in Durga Show) violates Art.22(5); must consider expeditiously

anchor.surface_text: Then the question is what is the effect of this unexplained delay of 17 days... In Durga Show etc. v. The State of West Bengal , this Court had to consider the effect... delay of 16 days... is a long delay

anchor.surface_text: The various decisions... deal with... Preventive Detention Act, 1950, but the provisions... substantially similar... principles apply... We have already held that there is an unexplained delay of 17 days... sufficient ground

holdings.text: We are of the opinion that the contention of Mr. Manchanda that there has been a delay in the State in passing orders on the representation made by the petitioners and that the said delay has not been properly explained by the State, has, in the circumstances of this case, to be accepted. In consequence, it follows that there has been a violation of the constitutional right guaranteed under Art. 22(5) to the petitioners. We are further of the view that the detention orders will have, to be struck down on this short ground.

anchor.surface_text: We are of the opinion that the contention of Mr. Manchanda that there has been a delay in the State in passing orders on the representation made by the petitioners and that the said delay has not been properly explained by the State, has,

holdings.reasoning_summary: State failed to provide detailed explanation including steps taken, correspondence, or affidavits from relevant officials; bald assertions insufficient given easy availability of information.

holdings.text: prima facie we are satisfied that the grounds are neither vague nor devoid of particulars, nor can it be said that in this case there were no materials on the basis of which the detaining authority could have passed the orders of detention under s. 3(2) read with s. 3(1) of the Act for the purpose mentioned therein on the basis of the grounds furnished to the petitioners.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Court reviewed grounds and found them sufficiently particularized with dates, times, places; petitioners made elaborate representation without seeking further details.

holdings.text: it must be held that there has been an unexplained delay of 17 days in this case in the Government disposing of the representation of the detenus.

anchor.surface_text: From what is stated above, it is clear that the State was fully aware... it must be held that there has been an unexplained delay of 17 days in this case in the Government disposing of the representation of the detenus.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No averments on nature of enquiries (oral/written), timelines, correspondence between officials, or supporting affidavits from SDC, Jailor; letter from Jailor lacks reference to prior communication.

holdings.text: the provisions of the Act, with which we are dealing, in all material respects, are substantially similar to the Preventive Detention Act, 1950. Hence the principles laid down by this Court in the above decisions apply on all fours to the matter on hand.

anchor.surface_text: The various decisions... deal with... Preventive Detention Act, 1950, but the provisions... substantially similar... principles apply... We have already held that there is an unexplained delay of 17 days... sufficient ground

holdings.reasoning_summary: OPDA provisions on representation disposal analogous to PDA 1950; precedents on expeditious consideration binding here.

holdings.text: there is an unexplained delay of 17 days between the date when the representation was received by the Administrator, namely, March 3, 1971 and when the latter considered the representation and passed the order rejecting the same on March 20, 1971. If that is so, without anything more, that circumstance by itself is a sufficient ground for holding that the orders of detention of the petitioners are illegal and they are entitled to, be, released.

anchor.surface_text: We have already held that there is an unexplained delay of 17 days between the date when the representation was received by the Administrator, namely, March 3, 1971 and when the latter considered the representation and passed the order rejecting the same on March 20, 1971. If that is so, without anything more, that circumstance by itself is a sufficient ground for holding that the orders of detention of the petitioners are illegal and they are entitled to, be, released.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Unexplained delay breaches dual obligation under Art.22(5) to expeditiously consider representation independent of Advisory Board; follows precedents like Durga Shaw (16 days), Khairul Haque, Jayanarayan Sukul establishing vitiation of detention.

edges.explanation: The concept c4 under Section 7 Orissa Preventive Detention Act, 1970 mandates furnishing grounds of detention to the detenu to enable effective representation, which directly addresses the issue i2 concerning vagueness of grounds preventing such representation.
